title: How to Calculate a Digital Camera's Resolution from its Pixel Count

steps.headline: Find out the aspect ratio of your camera.
steps.description:
Here are the two most common:

3:2, or 3 horizontal pixels for each 2 vertical pixels, is typical for digital SLRs. 4:3, or 4 horizontal pixels for each 3 vertical pixels, is the aspect ratio used by most compact (point-and-shoot) cameras in their still mode.

steps.headline: Convert your megapixel count to a total pixel count by multiplying it by 1 million, if necessary.
Get a horizontal-to-vertical and vertical-to-horizontal ratio.
steps.description: You get the horizontal-to-vertical ratio by dividing the first part of your aspect ratio by the second; you get the vertical-to-horizontal ratio by dividing the second part of your aspect ratio by the third. In our 3:2 digital SLR example:

steps.headline: Multiply your pixel count by the horizontal-to-vertical ratio, then separately, by your vertical-to-horizontal ratio.
Take the square root of your resulting numbers.
You now have the resolution of the camera.
steps.description: In the case of our imaginary digital SLR, it was 4243 x 2828.

text:
Find out the aspect ratio of your camera. Here are the two most common:

3:2, or 3 horizontal pixels for each 2 vertical pixels, is typical for digital SLRs. 4:3, or 4 horizontal pixels for each 3 vertical pixels, is the aspect ratio used by most compact (point-and-shoot) cameras in their still mode. Convert your megapixel count to a total pixel count by multiplying it by 1 million, if necessary.  Get a horizontal-to-vertical and vertical-to-horizontal ratio. You get the horizontal-to-vertical ratio by dividing the first part of your aspect ratio by the second; you get the vertical-to-horizontal ratio by dividing the second part of your aspect ratio by the third. In our 3:2 digital SLR example: Multiply your pixel count by the horizontal-to-vertical ratio, then separately, by your vertical-to-horizontal ratio.  Take the square root of your resulting numbers.  You now have the resolution of the camera. In the case of our imaginary digital SLR, it was 4243 x 2828. Finished.
sentences: Find out the aspect ratio of your camera.

Here are the two most common:

3:2, or 3 horizontal pixels for each 2 vertical pixels, is typical for digital SLRs.
4:3, or 4 horizontal pixels for each 3 vertical pixels, is the aspect ratio used by most compact (point-and-shoot) cameras in their still mode.
Convert your megapixel count to a total pixel count by multiplying it by 1 million, if necessary.
Get a horizontal-to-vertical and vertical-to-horizontal ratio.

You get the horizontal-to-vertical ratio by dividing the first part of your aspect ratio by the second; you get the vertical-to-horizontal ratio by dividing the second part of your aspect ratio by the third.
In our 3:2 digital SLR example: Multiply your pixel count by the horizontal-to-vertical ratio, then separately, by your vertical-to-horizontal ratio.
Take the square root of your resulting numbers.
You now have the resolution of the camera.
In the case of our imaginary digital SLR, it was 4243 x 2828.
